Situation1: A heated dispute has escalated to the point where they are questioning staying together.
Situation2: An irate long-time customer challenges the legitimacy of the offer and demands thorough explanations.
Story:
My phone buzzed with a new call just as my girlfriend’s voice rose, trembling with frustration. “Do you even care about us anymore?” she demanded, eyes red from arguing. My heart pounded—I knew this was the moment to fix things, to show her I was committed, to resolve the fight before it broke us. But the call was from work, and as a telemarketer, I couldn’t ignore it. I put her on hold, promising I’d be right back, and switched lines.

“Your company’s been calling me for years,” the customer snapped, “and now you’re telling me this offer is real? Prove it.” His anger was palpable, and I was expected to stay calm, answer every question, and keep him from hanging up. My mind raced between the two worlds—my girlfriend’s tearful silence in the other room, the customer’s relentless demands in my ear. Both needed me, both expected me to fix things, but I could feel myself being pulled apart, unable to give either what they deserved.
